content.description: A crimpy, dynamic climb that is unfortunately a bit cramped due to the tree.  Sit start with your back to the flora with two crimps and follow the crimps out right until making a big move up to a hold on the faint arete.  Pull on through to the top.
content.location: On the Rainforest/Valley boulder between the downclimb and the Pocket Problem.

content.description:
Start sitting at the bottom of the arete on some sharp quartz holds. Move leftwards along the arete via sharp quartz slopers, crystals, edges and jugs to a somewhat tricky top out. This climb is kind of like a slightly harder, much sharper version of 'General Lee'. 

  If you can tolerate the pain, this climb is actually fairly enjoyable.
content.location: If you're looking at the 'Pocket Problem', turn 180 degrees and you will see a small boulder approx 75 feet away. This problem is located on that boulder, starting on the right arete of the short overhanging face.

content.description:
A short, powerful problem.  Sit start on a good flat hold on the arete.  Finesse your way up into two underclings at waist level, then step high and slap out right for the crystal (crux).  Crimp hard and stand up to a better hold out left before topping out. 

  Someone attacked this problem with a brush not long ago and yielded new but useless holds out left.
content.location: On the back arete of the Rainforest boulder, away from the trail.  Shares a common starting hold with All Purpose.

content.description:
Sit start on the right side of the huge flake. Move up into the jug then progress up with good feet to a slopey top out. This is a fun balancy route. 

  or an alternate description... 

  This is a really good V0. Start on a huge flake that looks like the head of a dog. The flake also continues down right. Find feet and move right hand above head up to a pretty good sloper. Bump right foot up into the flake onto an awesome foot. Bump right hand up and left (crossing over your head) to a good crimp with a killer thumb catch. Pull up and match. Next get high feet and stand up. Super fun!
content.location: On the boulder with 'Never Ending Scrubber' and 'Janet Gets a Wirebrush'. This starts sitting on the right side of the flake that also makes up the start of 'Never Ending Scrubber'

content.description: A quick, five move problem that is both dynamic and shouldery, but the holds are friendly.  Start standing with two cool pocket-like holds above your head, plant a foot on the large shelf and dyno up and left to a very specific spot on the faint arete.  Plant a right foot on one of the small nubs and power out left again to the flat jug shelf.  Match and finish up.
content.location: On the Rainforest/Valley Boulder, between Valley Girls and the Firecracker Arete.  Downclimb using a tree to the left of the problem.

content.description: Listed as "Unnamed" in the Kemple guide, this one starts with the same obvious pocket as Pocket Problem but use the pocket with your left hand and right hand on a small edge, with a good foot move out right to an intermediate and then a ledge jug and top out.
content.location: On the Valley Boulder.  Find the start of Pocket Problem climb up and right.

content.description: Although listed as V2 in the guidebook, this tricky face climb doesn't feel anything like V2 even on the best of days.  Stand start with a pair of crimps at about the 4' level and choose how you will proceed.  Either power into the undercling with small feet and then toss for the good crimp, or skip the undercling with a toe hook and grab a high left edge before reaching up to the crimp.  Stick the lip and mantle over.  It's fun either way.
content.location: From the Rainforest Boulder (Valley Boulder) follow the wash towards the Method Boulder for about 100 feet and you'll see this slightly overhanging face.  Walk off the back.

content.description: Start standing with both hands on a good, high flake. Pull off the ground and work left via slopers, edges and eventually jugs, finishing at the apex of the arete.
content.protection: Pad and make sure you cover the large rock behind you. Turn around and jump off when done.
content.location: Same boulder as Jane Gets A Wirebrush. This boulder is on your left when walking from the Hero Block to the Valley Boulders. This boulder is slightly off the trail but easily visible. 'Never Ending Scrubber' is the right arete of the face that greets you as you approach the boulder from 'Firecracker'.

content.description: Start standing with your left hand on a good crimp/edge on the arete. Your right hand can start matched on this hold, or on small holds out right. Pull on, grab a fragile undercling/sidepull with your right and slap to a fairly bad sloper on the arete. Now sort out a way to get yourself to the top! Top out at the apex of the boulder.
content.location: 'Janet Gets A Wirebrush' climbs the left arete that faces the trail.

content.description:
Stand start with the right hand on a bad three finger divot on the arete and left hand down and left on the overhang on an obvious sloping seam. Find some feet and pull on with difficulty. Once established, make a hard move lefty to the good flat horizontal in the middle of the overhang. Match this rail then move up to a sweet pinch before a hard cross into the crack. The holds get better at the top, but the topout is still tricky.

 This is a right start into "Firecracker". Don't think the full sit start is a thing or if it would be very good.
content.location: The obvious right arete of the trailside classic "Firecracker". There are three scrubbed spots on the arete. This problem starts righty on the more positive slopey scrubbed spot.

content.description: A powerful problem that starts with the right hand low in the crack, that runs straight up the boulder. Left hand on a small edge on the arete. Use real good feet to power up to a positive crimp. Move left foot to a bad, but sticky foot. Bump right hand up in the crack (crux for me). One last throw to a sloper and the "business" is done. Then top out on good slopers.
content.protection: Pad and a spotter would be nice for the last move but not necessary.
content.location: Valley boulder on the face that faces the trail. Right hand in the crack and left on the arete. One step left of Firecracker.

content.description: Start with both hands on a decent face hold, then move up and to the left past the crack.  Move up again to the top (some tricky foot beta will help) and mantel the finish.
content.protection: pads and spotters certainly make you feel better.
content.location: When the trail splits go to the left, Firecracker is in the second group of boulders (at the bottom of a short steep hill.) It is up a crack which will be on your right when you are on the trail.

content.description:
Start sitting on the left arete. There are a couple different options for starting holds. I used a terrible sidepull crimp for my right hand and a slightly better sidepull crimp, around the corner from the arete, with my left hand. Pull off the ground with difficulty and slap up and right to an angled sloper on the lip. Match the lip with the left hand and fight for a couple more moves to reach better holds. Throw a heel on and press out a reasonably easy mantel. The first few moves are definitely the crux. 

  Short and stout! Good conditions definitely help. But, no matter what the conditions, this climb will likely destroy your skin. 

  I can't say I recommend this climb, but it might be worth doing if you've run out of things to climb or you consider yourself a masochist.
content.location: Located on the same boulder as 'Sharp Arete'. This small block is about 75 feet to the left of the Valley Boulder (when facing Firecracker).

content.description: Sit start on small edges and decent feet, move up and left to an edge and gain the fun topout.
content.location: Right side of Valley Boulder. Obvious sit starting edges.

content.description: sit start and climb the positive holds on the blunt nose. The sit start is the crux because of the weird holds, they are not as positive as the holds on the rest of the route. From the start pull up and climb the flakes and decent feet to the top out. The top out can be a little dirty but its all there.
content.protection: Pad and spotter for the rock you could fall on.
content.location: On the Valley Boulder on the right face (if facing firecracker V2) it is the blunt nose/arete.

content.description: This problem is so inviting. A really long slopey arete that goes from left to right. Start on two good side pull crimps; pull up to the slopey arete and continue right on really good feet. Top-out at the highest point of this boulder.
content.protection: Pad and someone to move the pad. An actual spotter isn't necessary. Down climb bu the dead trees and jump off. I went to the lowest part of the boulder and jumped onto a pad. Which is also an option.
content.location: Walking from Hero Block to the Valley Boulder it is on your left. It is visible from the trail but a little bit off of the trail. This route starts around on the other side of the boulder.

content.description: Sit start the slab with a left hand gaston and a right hand rail. Find a way onto the wall and climb up the crimpy technical dihedral feature to a blind move to a horizontal seam and a slopey top.
content.location: This problem is about 30 yards off of the main trail on the left when passing "Firecracker". It is also directly behind "El Scorcho" and "Sharp Arete".

content.description:
Sit start on the arete on the backside of the boulder. Pull on edges and work up and right using crimps, sidepulls, and body tension before a big move to the top out this great climb.

 Great climb for a friction heavy day, miserable if it is humid.
content.location: Right side of the Valley Boulder. Right next to the trail.

content.description: Sitting between the Hero Block and The Method Area, these four boulders are tucked away in a small valley and can frequently be waterlogged.  Not to be missed are the fun Firecracker, the dynamic Pocket Problem, and the short but stout Rubber Cement.
